case_vignette: A 74-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden-onset, painless vision loss in his left eye. He describes the feeling as if things went black in his left eye suddenly. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves III-XII as intact. The patient is unable to see out of his left eye but has normal vision in his right eye. The rest of his exam including strength, sensation, and gait are unremarkable. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A and an ultrasound of the eye is performed as seen in Figure B. Fundoscopy is performed as seen in Figure C. A CT scan of the head is currently pending.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my left eye; it went completely black.
How old are you?
I am 74 years old.
Do you have any history of high blood pressure or diabetes?
Yes, I have a history of type II diabetes.
Are you currently taking any medications for your diabetes? And if yes, what medications are you taking?
As a patient, I can confirm that I'm taking medications for my diabetes, but I cannot specify which ones I'm taking.
Do you have any family history of similar eye problems or neurological conditions?
I don’t know, nobody ever mentioned anything like that in the family.

Thank you for the information. Based on your symptoms, medical history, and age, I have a good idea of what might be causing your vision loss. I would recommend you see a doctor right away for further evaluation and treatment.

No, there's no pain, just the sudden loss of vision in my left eye.

Thank you for providing that information. Based on your symptoms, medical history, and risk factors, I suspect you may be experiencing a condition called Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO).

This condition can be a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. Please seek medical assistance right away.

**Final Diagnosis:** Central Retinal Artery Occlusion
